- Private sector employees are not legally allowed to set aside as much money for retirement as many public sector employees are.  Public sector retirement contributions can be up to 25% of gross compensation, while there is a 18% cap on contributions to RRSPs in the private sector

- Public sector total compensation, for a large number of jobs, vastly exceeds that in the private sector.  Looking just at wages might not show a huge gap, but when you add in the value of "employer paid" pension contributions the public sector workers are often compensated at a much higher level than comparable workers in the private sector.  The only exceptions are near the very top of the income chain where people like lawyers and executives can often do better in the private sector.  For entry-level positions (note the comment above about "save early in life") the gap is particularly large.

Comment: I recall commenting on the definition of assault, but I made no comment on how much force would be required for it to be an assault.

In all cases a primary consideration is consent. If the parties consent to force being applied to one another, then a great deal of it can be applied lawfully, as in contact sports. On the other hand if one party hasn't consented to it then no force may be exerted on him or her, except by peace officers in the course of their duties.

A pat on the back or touching someone's arm requires an application of force, as does shaking someone's hand. However these are common gestures that wouldn't be assault under normal circumstances. Consent is implied in those cases because they're normal human interactions.. However, should the other party withdraw consent to being touched, then you can't touch them in any way, without risk of it being an assault.

Comment: The regulation knee-jerk statement "ensure that all profits are duly taxed in the country where the productive and commercial activities take place" avoids one vital piece of information:
If goods are manufactured in a company's home factories (say, in Europe) and the exported to another country (say, in Africa) for sale by a subsidiary company of the manufacturer, how is the profit to be divided "for taxation purposes"?  
Two figures can be established without much dispute: the cost of production, (for these purposes including "overheads" such as transport costs and any customs duties payable), and the actual selling price.  The difference between these is then the ("bottom-line") nett profit.  How is this to be divided for taxation purposes between the two countries involved?  At best, the division is arbitrary, and the subject of immense debate.

Comment: _"how affordable does Eugene need to be?"_

That is a very insightful question, which hasn't even gotten a quick look by staff working on Envision Eugene.

It's too deep a topic to do justice here, but there are multiple facets: subsidized housing, workforce housing, family-friendly housing are all aspects of the question.

Subsidies are not a good, generalized solution, although I support housing subsidies for some situations. Zoning and developer incentives are critical. And finally, there must be adequate supply of developable land. Community-driven planning (real, not the sham we have here) is the best way to get some plans on the table that the community would support and might actually do some good.

The problem in Eugene is that the "Emperor has no clothes" and yet the Mayor and council majority (and sadly the primary voters) seem content.

The stuff that comes out of our Planning & Development Department is pitiful, and yet there's no accountability.

And so it goes ...

- Paul
